content.description:
This is an awesome climb with delicate and powerful moves.

 Sit-start matched on the overhanging arete. Make a big move up lefthand to a positive incut found on the arete, this is the same first move as "Growler". Once on this hold, hand-toe-match the starthold and press out onto the slab up to a shark-tooth gaston. Figure out how to come in to the sloping sidepull for the lefthand before spanning out right to a positive sidepull for the right hand. Once here, find some feet and execute a committing and powerful move up to a positive shelf at the lip of the boulder. Hold the tension and come in for the match before topping out.
content.protection: 4 or 5 pads. The landing is a bit sketchy and the last move is full span unless you punch up to it lefty and hold the barndoor.
content.location: This problem starts on the right overhanging arete found on the uphill side of the Asteroid Boulder and finishes more or less directly above the start.

content.description: Start low with a crimp sidepull and a sloping rail for the right hand. Move up to a left hand sidepull, then make a hard cross to a sloping rail. Once here, make a hard, delicate and balancy foot move, then reach up to a gaston. ("Celestial Shores" finishes as for "Meteora" from here, whereas this problem continues left.) From here, figure out how to match and then make a big span left to a sidepull. Walk the feet and gain a sloping gaston for the right and execute the super classic lock-off and last move of "Howler Direct Assis". This climb links from the start of "Asteroid" all the way into "Howler Direct". This problem provides some great, super delicate and technical climbing on sloping holds with long reaches between those holds.
content.protection: 5-6 pads. The landing has a few tiers and a hole os located underneath "Howler".
content.location: This problem starts about 15 feet to the right of "Growler" (Pulled Pork Arete). There is a somewhat obvious right hamd sloping rail, and a bitey left hand sidepull for the left.

content.description:
Just a variation to The Kosher Option. Same start, but go left to the tiny crimp for Pulled Pork then gaston on it and lock off to the jug Kosher Option dynos to. Might be easier for shorties than the full Kosher Option dyno.

 As for Kosher Option you can either start at the Pulled Pork start and add a grade or start on the arete and call it an 8.
content.location: The Kosher Option/Pulled Pork

content.description: Stand start with a right hand on a curved crimp and left hand on a sharp edge in the brown/orange part and pop up to a nice sloper above your right hand then work your way up the arete a bit and pull over it or continue up the arete to top out above Growler for more climbing. Probably closer to V4 with full arete top out.
content.protection: pads
content.location: to the right of Asteroid

content.description: Sit start below and to the left of the obvious crimp rail. Move right to an interesting pocket on the arete, then follow the arete to top out. Crimpy, technical, and fun!
content.protection: Pad or two and a spotter. The slab behind is slippery, so watch out for that.
content.location: On the steep underside of Asteroid Boulder uphill from the Impossible Problem.

content.description: Squat start with a right hand mono and a slopey left hand sidepull pinch. Find some feet and do a hard left hand move up to a good edge, then venture directly up the slab with an exciting last move to the lip.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and a spotter. Last move is committing.
content.location: This problem is just a few feet left of the steep overhang that is home to "Boomerang" and "Pulled Pork". The mini is pretty easy to locate.

content.description:
A powerful and technical climb that is quite delicate and friction dependent.

 Stand start with a high right hand sloping crimp and a low left hand sloping sidepull that is barely a hold. Pick a foot and tense up to pull onto the face. Stay tight and reach up lefty to a gaston. Stick to it and jack the feet up with difficulty before making a hard committing move to a large rail up and right. Match this rail and throw a foot up and top out on large positive holds.

 This is a great committing addition to the wall that climbs its own independent line.
content.protection: 2-3 pads. Landing is tiered, but flat. You start standing on the high tier, then all the falls tend to be onto the lower tier for the "Asteroid" landing, which is fairly flat and safe.
content.location: This climb is found to the right of "Growler" and "Howler" and to the left of "Asteroid".

content.description: This is a great technical, delicate yet powerful face climb.Stand start with a low left hand sidepull crimp and a right hand sloping horizontal rail. Find some feet and establish onto the wall. Pull up to a sharp lefthand crimp or a slopey sidepull with a good thumb-catch. Once here, figure out how to reach up to a high sloping rail. Latch this hold then make a few more hard balance moves and some fun tension moves to gain jugs at the lip then execute a nice airy mantle onto the top of the Asteroid.Down climb by walking down the long slab, or the backside with some friendly birch trees.
content.protection: 3 pads. The landing has a tier, but most of the falls are very easily protectable. Have a spotter just in case.
content.location: This problem is found almost dead center on the long slab face of the boulder. To the right of "Pulled Pork" and "Howler". It is found between "Meteora" and "Asteroid"The right hand starting hold is used as the left-hand starting hold for "Asteroid". This problem is a lower, more full value line into the fun problem "Meteora".

content.description:
Sit start with an awesome, super friction dependent, left hand pinch on the arete and a nearly unusable sloping quartz blob on the steep overhang. Find some bad feet and make a super hard move up to a blind jug on the arete. Keep the foot tension of take the shouldery foot cut and avoid the dab before continuing and staying true to the arete until one can rock over onto a good toe found to mantle. Shares the same xit as "Boomerang" and "Pulled Pork".

 This is the full line into "Boomerang Arete". It adds a one move at V-hard into the V4. Clearly it has been lost in conversion, or people simply can't pinch hard enough to send it. A more impressive send than "Boomerang" and likely harder than any move on "Pulled Pork".
content.protection: 2-3 pads. There are a few blocks around one could get injured on. The problem is very shouldery as well. Do your arm circles, or blow out a shoulder, your pick.
content.location:
This problem climbs the left arete of the triangular shaped overhang from a low sit start.

 The sit into "Boomerang Arete".

content.description: Start as for Pulled Pork but once you reach the arete match in the main hand hold and get a foot on the arete, rock over the arete and stand up on your right toe and reach for the jug about 6ish feet up from the arete.
content.protection: pads
content.location: boomerang boulder

content.description:
Sit start with both hands on the arete. Make a hard first move up to a 3 finger edge found on the arete.  (This is the same first move as  Growler.) Once here figure out how to mantle onto the slab and reach out for a small gaston on the face, figure out how to move the left hand then make a few more long reaches on slopey dishes and crimps before making a final desperate huck for the lip or a rail just shy of it!

 A superb climb that takes a lot of balance technique and power!
content.protection: 4 pads, maybe more. It is a bit exposed!
content.location: This line is found on the right side of the steep overhang and climbs up and slightly leftwards on sloping dishes and small crimps.

content.description: I've seen many people miss this fine line by starting too far right... Step onto the center of the face to the right of pulled pork gaining a series of small crimps. Using a very high left foot rock up and stretch way up and left until you can gain a small sloper. From there head straight up using a series of increasingly small crimps - finally using a thumb down (right hand) in order to gain enough elevation to make a blind reach to the top edge.
content.protection: a few pads  - you drop directly into a hole among the rocks at the base

content.description: Sit start with hands at the block on the arete.  Fire up to a crimp pocket along the arete up and left, then continue into the jug on Pulled Pork.  Follow Pulled Pork to the finish passing through a series of crimps to the insecure mantle
content.protection: The mantle is pretty tough as the top of the boulder is very slick, be mindful of this
content.location: Left of Pulled Pork along the arete

content.description: Starts on the arete to the immediate left of Boomerang. Start under opposing sidepulls/edges and move up into the side pulls/edges. Climb right towards Boomerang using edges in the crack and top out on the slabby face above Boomerang.
content.protection: pads
content.location: A few feet to the left of Boomerang, well before the Shelf problem if coming from Boomerang.

content.description: On the steep underside of Asteroid Boulder uphill from the Impossible Problem. Grab an upside-down layback hold, smear your feet and gun for a sloping crimp just shy of the lip. Some tricky footwork is needed to grab the lip, then mantle. Shares the same start at Pulled Pork
content.protection: boulder
content.location: Located on the Asteroid Boulder uphill from the Impossible Problem

content.description:
Found the real name! Updated it. 

  Starts on a high rail at 6ish feet. Swing your foot up to the big shelf then match a hand next to it and drop the foot down into a heel hook. Reach up for a jug and top out using the high arrete.
content.protection: pads
content.location: Located on the same boulder as Boomerang. Go down to the left of Boomerang until you see graffiti on the boulder, its right past this.

content.description:
I finally got the name of this and updated it, its actual name is Body Slam.

 Start low to the right of the stand start with a right hand on the arete and left hand on a tiny edge far out left. Make a quick move to an edge on the lip below the rail for the stand start, get a slopey hold with your right then climb into the stand start and finish.
content.protection: pads
content.location: Down to the left of Boomerang past the graffiti.

content.description: Sit start on the sloping arete as for "Body Slam". Pull on and stick a big move up the arete to a positive hold then rock out onto the slab and venture up directly to the top. The crux revolves around some sidepulls and some small crimps near the top.
content.protection: 3-5 pads
content.location: The backside overhang of the boulder.

content.description:
A link-up of Body Slam and Bill Don't Dyno. Climb Body Slam to the sloping shelf (starting hold of Body Slam Stand), then traverse down to the far left side. Dyno from here to the lip, where you'll encounter a somewhat tricky top-out. A spotter could be helpful, as there are a few big blocks underneath you. 

 A bit silly, but actually pretty fun.
content.location: Start as for Body Slam (there's a great description and image marking the starting holds on that route page).

content.description: Start on the left side of the shelf, same start as the dyno, and climb to the right into Body Slam
content.protection: pads
content.location: Left of body slam

content.description: Start on the far left of the Body Slam block (the shelf-like bulge) and dyno out to the left lip. A nice fun dyno for Smuggs. Shoot for the lip, not the weird chicken head jug thing that stands up over the lip.
content.protection: pads
content.location: Left of Body Slam

content.description: Squat start with both hands matched on the sloping crimp rail. Pull onto the slabby wall with difficulty and make a hard move up and right to improving edges while opposing the barn door. Stay tight and go for improving holds on the lip of the boulder. The top out is fairly exposed but not difficult.
content.protection: 2 pads
content.location: This line is found about 10 or so feet to the right of Growler, on the other side of the tree.

content.description: Lots of excellent climbs on some of the best rock in the notch.
